channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Assad Frames Syria Struggle as Him Against Western Colonizers
item.description: An interview Wednesday on Syria’s Independence Day suggested that President Bashar al-Assad’s views on the country’s two-year civil war have only hardened.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By HANIA MOURTADA

item.title: No Deal Yet in Serbia and Kosovo Talks to Ease Tensions
item.description: The countries have agreed on the broad principle that Serbs in a Serbian-majority area in northern Kosovo would gain more powers and tacitly recognize Kosovo’s government.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: A resident of the ethnically divided town of Mitrovica in Kosovo, which may grant more autonomy to majority Serbs in the north.

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Honduras: Attorney General Is Suspended
item.description: Saying it was frustrated with some of the worst criminal violence in the world, the Honduran congress suspended the attorney general and his assistant.
item.dc:creator: By KARLA ZABLUDOVSKY

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Mubarak to Be Moved to Prison
item.description: Egypt’s chief prosecutor on Wednesday ordered the transfer of former President Hosni Mubarak from a Cairo military hospital back to prison.
item.dc:creator: By MAYY EL SHEIKH

item.title: World Briefing | South Pacific: New Zealand: Gay Marriage Bill Passes
item.description: Parliament on Wednesday voted 77 to 44 to legalize same-sex marriage, making New Zealand the 13th nation in the world and the first in the Asia-Pacific region to allow gay couples to marry.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Europeans Step Toward Easing Syria Oil Exports
item.description: European Union members reached a preliminary agreement as part of an effort to make opposition-held areas self-sufficient, diplomats said.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: Fighters with the Free Syrian Army taking positions on the roof of a building in the eastern city of Deir al-Zour.

item.title: Key Obama Officials Differ on Syria in Testimony
item.description: The differing assessments came as the White House was considering what next steps to take in a conflict that has killed more than 70,000 and defied resolution.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: A Syrian boy salvaged items from a garbage dump on Wednesday in the war-ravaged northern Syrian city of Aleppo. The war there has killed more than 70,000.

item.title: National Briefing | Washington: Court Declines to Rule in Wikileaks Complaint
item.description: A military appeals court on Wednesday declined to rule on a lawsuit seeking greater access for journalists to court filings and proceedings in the criminal case against Pfc. Bradley Manning.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SHANE

item.title: Thatcher Funeral Draws Dignitaries and Complaints
item.description: The ceremonial funeral with military honors for Margaret Thatcher has divided British opinion, much as the former prime minister stirred passions in her lifetime.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN F. BURNS and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: The coffin holding the body of Margaret Thatcher was carried up the steps of St. Paul's Cathedral in London on Wednesday.

item.title: Report on Iran Urges Obama to Rethink Sanctions
item.description: A panel of former senior American officials, including several Obama administration alumni, asked the president to reconsider the likelihood that harsh sanctions will drive Tehran to concessions.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: More Children in Greece Start to Go Hungry
item.description: Greece’s economic free-fall is reshaping the lives of families with children, many of whom arrive at school hungry, underfed or even malnourished.
item.dc:creator: By LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:credit: Angelos Tzortzinis for the International Herald Tribune
item.media:description: Michalis Petrakis, who is jobless and whose son Pantelis has been going to school hungry, opened his nearly empty refrigerator.

item.title: I.M.F. Warns of Risk as Company Debt Grows
item.description: In an annual report, the International Monetary Fund said that governments must remain vigilant in structural and banking changes to avoid a financial crisis.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Some Italians Push for Next President to Be a Woman
item.description: While women hold a record 31 percent of the seats in Parliament, Italy has lagged other European countries in equality for women over all.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:description: Interior Minister Anna Maria Cancellieri, here with Prime Minister Mario Monti, has been mentioned as a possible president.

item.title: Kerry Encourages Recount in Venezuela
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry suggested a recount in the presidential vote and said he had not yet evaluated whether Washington would recognize Nicolás Maduro’s victory.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nicolás Maduro greeting supporters in Caracas after it was announced that he won a vote to succeed President Hugo Chávez.

item.title: Mazar-I-Sharif Journal: Mazar-i-Sharif’s Economic Success Extends to Its Sex Trade
item.description: Mazar-i-Sharif has become the unofficial capital of prostitution — so much so that “going to Mazar” has become an expression for men looking to pay for sex.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palusha, with young relatives, is a former prostitute who started an embroidery and sewing operation in her home in the northern Afghan city of Mazar-i-Sharif.

item.title: Company Founder Makes Court Appearance in Breast-Implant Case
item.description: Jean-Claude Mas, of Poly Implants Prothèses, is accused of selling hundreds of thousands of defective implants to more than 65 countries.
item.dc:creator: By MAÏA de la BAUME

item.title: IHT Special : Lebanon Pins Economic Hopes on Oil and Gas
item.description: Potential revenue from oil and gas deposits off Lebanon's coast is being offered as a salve for the country's many problems.
item.dc:creator: By JOSH WOOD

item.title: Lens Blog: Vitas Luckus, Once a Luminary of the Soviet Photography Scene
item.description: Vitas Luckus’s obsession with photographing the Soviet bloc won praise from admirers and beatings from officials. His work faded into obscurity after his death, but his widow is helping to revive his reputation.
item.dc:creator: By JULIE TURKEWITZ

item.title: IHT Special : Restoring Iraq's Garden of Eden
item.description: Azzam Alwash, who this week received the Goldman Environmental Prize, is focused on reviving the massive oasis in the desert that biblical scholars say may have been the Garden of Eden.
item.dc:creator: By ERICA GIES

item.title: IHT Special : Jordanian Activists Struggle On
item.description: Members of Jordanian opposition movements say they are increasingly disillusioned by economic hardship and by regional violence across the border, especially in neighboring Syria.
item.dc:creator: By RANA F. SWEIS

item.title: The Lede: Blogger Who Traced Flow of Arms to Syria Through YouTube Seeks Crowdfunding
item.description: The British blogger Eliot Higgins, who writes on the war in Syria under the pen name Brown Moses, began an appeal for financial support from readers this week.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Serbia and Kosovo Near Deal, Official Says
item.description: Serbia and Kosovo were edging toward a deal Wednesday aimed at overcoming ethnic enmities in the former Serbian province, a senior Kosovo official said.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Justices Bar U.S. Suit in Nigerian Human Rights Case
item.description: The decision severely limited the sweep of a 1789 law that had been used to address human rights abuses abroad.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By ADAM LIPTAK

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: April 17
item.description: A procession organized by eunuchs in Ajmer, Rajasthan.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Eunuchs organized a procession in Ajmer, Rajasthan, to demand better political representation in the national elections to be held next year.

item.title: Euro Zone Crisis Has Increased I.M.F.’s Power
item.description: Christine Lagarde, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, has become as influential as a head of state in Europe, causing controversy both inside and outside the region.
item.dc:creator: By JACK EWING
item.media:description: Christine Lagarde, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, with Wolfgang Schäuble, the German finance minister, in June 2012.
